Indulge me yet awhile: — with fond delay</br>Indulge me yet.  Too swiftly speeds the hour</br>When I must leave, though loth, this citron bow'r,</br>Yon rocks, yon isles, that Syren-haunted bay,</br>Green Chiaia's groves, Vesuvio's crest of light,</br>And Pausilippo's gloom, that makes the noon-day, night.

What though, ere-long, my lip with filial kiss</br>Will press the cliff that guards my native shore,</br>Though on my mother earth my knee adore</br>The Pow'r, the Guardian of domestic bliss,</br>Who from the perils of the land and main,</br>May in my peaceful home repose my brow again:

And though that peaceful home more lov'd appear</br>Because its threshold has so long been strange,</br>Nor though I would one household smile exchange</br>For all that Italy holds justly dear,</br>Yet, Albion!  when thy sullen mists sweep by,</br>I must regret yon sun that gilds th' Ausonian sky.

The dream will linger on the orb of light</br>Which upward draws the soft ethereal haze,</br>That the fierce burning of its beam allays,</br>And casts a magic colour on the sight:</br>And tempering, while it beautifies the scene,</br>Like a transparent veil, floats heav'n and earth between.

The dream will linger on the blest champain,</br>From hill to hill where groves of olive grew,</br>O'er which the grape her purple clusters threw;</br>While all beneath Earth wav'd with billowy grain,</br>And all around the golden orange glow'd,</br>And bow'rs along whose bloom the sea in shadow flow'd.

Fair was the dawn that led me on my way,</br>A Nymph, the star of Morn, before me flew,</br>And shook from her loose hair a show'r of dew:</br>The birds, whose melody awakes the day,</br>Trill'd their glad song in every bush and bow'r,</br>And fragrance round me breath'd from each unfolding flow'r.

There, as I pac'd along the winding bay,</br>I heard a whisper from each rock and cave,</br>That fann'd with gentle breath the sunny wave,</br>The while the balance that on ocean lay</br>Levell'd the waves throughout their tideless sweep,</br>And on the water fell like an untroubled sleep.

O man!  if reckless of thy pilgrimage,</br>If unrememb'ring that each transient hour</br>Bears on its stretch of wing a Guardian Pow'r,</br>The Angel of thy birth, thy youth, thy age,</br>Who graves each deed, and lifts it borne on high,</br>Before the awful throne that holds Eternity:

If thou at will might fix thy seat below,</br>A resting place beneath the cope of heav'n,</br>A paradise on earth to mortals giv'n,</br>Round thee her song Parthenope should throw,</br>And lulling to oblivion on her breast</br>Warble the Syren song that lays the soul to rest.

THE SYREN'S SONG.</br>"Rest, Wanderer, rest!  all nature sleeps:</br>'Tis noon-tide's slumberous hour:</br>O'er the smooth rock no lizard creeps,</br>No serpent stirs the bow'r,</br>And, curtain'd in the blushing rose,</br>The bees their wearied wings repose.

"The bird, at rest, forgets her song,</br>No cloud through heaven's blue zone</br>Strays while the noon-sun moves along,</br>And walks in light alone:</br>A quiet stills the world of waves,</br>And sea-nymphs sleep in coral caves.

"Then lay thee on my lap to rest,</br>While lazy suns wheel by,</br>There dream of her thou fanciest best,</br>And wake, and find her nigh;</br>And I will lead thee to a grove</br>Where hangs a lute attun'd to Love.

"That lute by Love to me was lent,</br>Sweet notes, and sad, there dwell;</br>Sweet as his voice that wins assent,</br>Sad as his breath'd farewell:</br>Yet — in its sadness, moving more</br>Than all that won thy smile before."

The Syren ceases:  yet, sure to wound,</br>'Mid jasmine arbors on Certosa's height,</br>Allures thee, when the sun's half-hidden light,</br>That the broad bay and isles in flame had bound,</br>From the smooth sea-line fades in purple gleam,</br>And gilds on Ischia's brow the clouds that watch his beam.

There, on the night-wind, as it swells and falls,</br>Bids, melted down by distance, from below,</br>One voice, from thousands and ten thousands, flow,</br>And die away at peaceful intervals,</br>And mingle with the murmur of the main,</br>Till on thy slumbrous lid her witchery hangs again.

Slumberer!  awake.  The scenes that round thee close</br>Are dark with horror.  There th' avenging wave</br>Unpeoples Baia:  from yon haunted grave</br>O'er her pale murderer Agrippina rose:</br>Nightly a curse maternal rends the air,</br>And Furies round that tomb erect their viper hair.

Lo!  Caprea — there, the monster's philter'd bowl</br>Was dregg'd with gore — and lo!  in after time</br>Yon palace darken'd with Joanna's crime:</br>There Death upheld his unrelenting scroll,</br>When Conrad stern in bloom and beauty stood,</br>And from the scaffold cast his gauntlet, gaged for blood.

Naples!  awake!  each stone that props thy sleep,</br>Burst from the riven womb of central fire.</br>Before thee, on Vesuvio's blazing pyre</br>Death swells the sea of flame that burst the steep,</br>And silencing a nation's voice of mirth,</br>O'er Herculaneum roll'd, and swept her race from earth.

Round thee, thy earth, thy sea, thy every isle</br>One element of fire.  On yonder brow</br>The blazing flood that drank the wave below</br>Tower'd in its rage o'er Epomeo's pile.</br>The blast sulphureous from Argnano flows,</br>And green Astroni's woods the crater's depth enclose.

Lo!  shaking off the dust that veil'd her tombs,</br>The shroud wherein her buried glory lay,</br>Pompeia, looking on the light of day,</br>'Mid living towns her birth-right reassumes,</br>And wondering why her sons in exile roam,</br>Lifts her maternal voice, and calls the wanderer home.

"Return!  why stay you?  Throng the festive gate:</br>For you these vaults reserve their hoarded wine:</br>Haste to yon forum:  heap with gifts this shrine:</br>Th' impatient theatres your press await:</br>The track your wheel has worn, the car shall greet;</br>Tread where each stone retains the pressure of your feet.

"Come." — but no voice yields response — none return.</br>Of all that living world the sole remain,</br>A captive's bone half-calcin'd with its chain,</br>The nameless dust its sepulchral urn;</br>And, as the lava harden'd on its rest,</br>That unrelenting mould which clasp'd the female breast.

How sweet is silence, when from worldly din</br>Freed Fancy shapes her own fair images,</br>And peoples all the solitude it sees</br>With the conceptions of the soul within,</br>Joy's youthful choir, or visions high and holy,</br>Or soft and soothing sounds of patient melancholy.

Not such the silence that inhabits here,</br>Not such the solitude around me spread:</br>This silence, is the silence of the dead;</br>This solitude but wakes a bitter tear,</br>A tear that falling on a nation's tomb</br>Deepens the mournful thoughts of man's uncertain doom.

The sun, methinks, has o'er me clos'd his beam,</br>The last low sigh, the fluttering pulse has ceas'd,</br>From joy, from woe, from hope, from fear releas'd,</br>I look on life as a departed dream,</br>And that already I have reach'd the bourn</br>Whence foot of mortal man shall never more return.

Pass on — What scenes of wonder flash on sight?</br>Where yon gay vineyards root their trained rows</br>In the thin soil, the breeze that freshly blows</br>Tosses in air the ashes' mantle light,</br>And porticoes and porches re-appear,</br>And halls for banquet deck'd their painted column rear.

What though no roof the radiant courts enclose,</br>Fantastic figures beaming from below</br>Along the rich Mosaic brightly glow:</br>All that from Raffael's fairy pencil flows</br>In graceful Arabesque, the walls adorn,</br>Wing'd nymphs that float in air, and wind the wreathed horn.

Now a wing'd Zephyr beckons to the sail,</br>And now, in all the brightness of her smile</br>A goddess woos thee to her blissful isle.</br>Here fruits bloom forth, there flow'rs that fear the gale</br>Drop from their opening bells bright pearls below,</br>Where sea-things wave their fins, and gambol to and fro.

Wanderer!  delay not. — Like a sun-built cloud</br>That travels in the swiftness of its ray,</br>Gleams on the sight, and swiftly glides away:</br>So these gay forms, now casting off their shroud,</br>All vanish on the evanescent air</br>With all their rainbow tints, — as fugitive, — as fair.</br>
